properties.title: Bogd Khairkhan Mountain / Богд Хайрхан уул
properties.description:
Decree #110 (May 16, 1995) by President Punsalmaagiin Ochirbat. Nationwide State Ceremonies: 1996, 2000, 2004, 2008, 2012.

Bogd Khairkhan Mountain is Mongolia’s — and perhaps the world’s — oldest officially and continuously protected site. In 1778 the Mongolian governor of Khuree (Urga, present day Ulan-Bator) Sanzaidorj requested approval of annual ceremonies to Bogd Khairkhan from Qianlong Emperor. The letter and reply from Beijing in Mongolian is kept in the Central State Archives of Mongolia. The deity associated with Bogd Khan is Dunjingarav, a ferocious male, who rides thirty-three grey horses (a symbol of shamanism) and has the mantra (a ritual originating in Buddhism) “um ma hum”. The sutra created by Triumphant Abbot Damtsagdorj (1781-1855) is currently used in worship rituals.

properties.title: Burkhan Khaldun Mountain / Бурхан Халдун уул
properties.description:
Decree #110 (May 16, 1995) by President Punsalmaagiin Ochirbat. Nationwide State Ceremonies: 1998, 2002, 2006, 2010, 2015

Burkhan Khaldun is one of the Khentii Mountains of northeastern Mongolia. The mountain has had a strong religious significance since being designated as such by Chinggis Khan in the twelfth century. The Khentii Province is believed to be the birthplace of Chinggis Khan in or around 1162, and Burkhan Khaldun Mountain is where he performed his ceremonies and communicated with his protector spirits and the Tengeri. Worship was formalized by Presidential Decree in 1995 and was inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site on 4 July 2015.

properties.title: Otgontenger Khairkhan Mountain / Отгонтэнгэр
properties.description:
Decree #110 (May 16, 1995) by President Punsalmaagiin Ochirbat. Nationwide State Ceremonies: 1995, 1999, 2003, 2007, 2011.

Otgontenger Mountain is capped with a permanent glacier and is the highest point of the Khangai mountain range, located in Buyant Bag of Otgon Soum, Zavkhan Province. Otgontenger was first decreed protected in 1779, again in 1911 by Bogdo Khan, and in 1992 after the People’s Republic. A Strictly Protected Area, it is worshipped every four years.  The Buddhist deity Ochirvaani, ferocious and male, is associated with Otgontenger. The sutra created by Lama Agvaanprinlaijamts (1860-1936) is read during the worship ceremonies at present.

properties.title: Altan Khukhii Mountain / Алтан Хөхий уул
properties.description:
Decree #44 by President Natsagiin Bagabandi on March 30, 2005. Nationwide State Ceremonies: 2005, 2009, 2013.

Altan Khukhii Mountain was designated a State Worshipped Mountain in 2010. The mountain is located in the Great Lakes basin of the Mongol Altai Range, 35 miles (50 km) north of Myangad Soum center and 95 miles (150 km) south of Ulaangom town.

properties.title: Darigangyn Altan Ovoo / Дарьгангын Алтан Овоо
properties.description:
Decree #57 by President Natsagiin Bagabandi on April 23, 2004. Nationwide State Ceremonies: 2004, 2008, 2012.

Darigangyn Altan Ovoo, also known as Dariganga Dari Ovoo (Golden Cairn), is a volcano in Dariganga Soum in Sukhbaatar Aimag. The Eighth Jebtsundamba Khutuktu Bogd Khan (1869-1924) declared Darigangyn Altan Ovoo an officially worshipped mountain. Bogd Khan was the preeminent living Buddha of Mongolia, who ranked third in the Lamaist-Buddhist ecclesiastical hierarchy, after the Dalai Lama and the Panchen Lama.

properties.title: Khan Khukhii / Хан хөхий
properties.description:
Decree #183 by President Nambaryn Enkhbayar on July 26, 2007. Nationwide State Ceremonies: 2008 and 2012.

Khan Khukhii Mountain, along with Khan Khukhii Lake, Khyargas and Airag lakes, and the headwaters of the Zavkhan and Khungui rivers, has been protected as a National Park since 2000. The area is also significant for the tumuli (ancient burial mounds) found there. Khan Khukhii has a female deity who is said to meet with the male deity of nearby Tagna Mountain every month.

properties.title: Sutai Khairkhan Mountain / Сутай Хайрхан уул
properties.description:
Decree #183 (July 26, 2007) by President Nambaryn Enkhbayar.  Nationwide State Ceremonies: 2008 and 2012.

Sutai Khairkhan Mountain is covered in glaciers, peaked with snow, and is home to rare and protected plants and animals. At an elevation of 13,845 feet (4,220 meters), it is the highest of the Gobi-Altai Mountains in the Central Asian plateau. The deity who belongs to Sutai Khairkhan is a pale lady whose look can pacify the fierce and cares for the poor. In the 17th century a sutra called “Sutai khany san” was created for worship, and the sutra continues to be used during current rituals.

properties.title: Suvrag Khairkhan Mountain / Суврага Хайрхан уул
properties.description:
Decree #183 (July 26, 2007) by President Nambaryn Enkhbayar. Nationwide State Ceremonies: 2011

Suvrag Khairkhan forms the eastern part of the Khangai Mountains in the Tsenkher Soum of the Arkjangai province. This State Worshipped Sacred Mountain has an elevation of 10,430 ft  feet (3,179 meters), and is noted for its forests, rocky surfaces and snow-capped peak.

properties.title: Altai Tavan Bogd / Алтай Таван богд
properties.description:
President Tsakhiagiin Elbegdorzh acknowledged August 24, 2012.

Gobi Gurvan Saikhan is a National Park. The land has been protected from development since 1963 and is home to more than 200 bird species, as well as protected species, such as snow leopards, wild camel, and ibex.

properties.title: Gobi Gurvan Saikhan / Говь гурван сайхан
properties.description:
President Tsakhiagiin Elbegdorzh acknowledged August 24, 2012. Nationwide State Ceremony: July 2014

Altai Tavan Bogd is a National Park and is home to over 10,000 Neolithic and Bronze Age Tsagaan Salaa rock paintings.
